about.name: Spencer Szabados
about.label: Graduate Student
about.email: My full name at gmail dot com
about.summary: Incoming PhD student at UBC working under Frank Wood. I completed a Master's in Computer Science at the University of Waterloo with, Yaoliang Yu, focusing on generative models, and an undergrad in Applied Math and Computer Science at the University of Manitoba, where I worked on data depth in the GADA Lab. I enjoy tackling challenging problems, especially in computational math, applied stats, and numerical methods. Outside of work, I'm an avid reader, mostly on topics relating to human decision making, finance, and sci-fi.

education.studyType: Doctor of Philosophy in Computer Science
Masters of Mathematics in Computer Science

work.name: Inverted AI
work.summary: Research graduate intern for autonomous navigation and planning.

work.name: hum.ai (prev. Coastal Carbon)
work.summary: Promoted from Graduate Intern. Continuing design, testing, and implementation of latent diffusion models for remote sensing of multi-spectral satellite data.

work.name: Coastal Carbon
work.summary: Design, testing (benchmark design), and implementation of latent diffusion models for remote sensing of multi-spectral satellite data.

work.name: University of Waterloo
work.summary: Teaching Assistant for CS116 - Introduction to Programming II, CS330 - Management Information Systems, CS335 - Computational Methods in Business and Finance. Responsible for the timely and accurate evaluation of individual works, covering the design and analysis of algorithms and data structures with adherence to established standards.
highlights: Numerical integration of Stochastic Differential Equations for Finance.

work.name: University of Manitoba
work.summary: Teaching Assistant for CS3170 - Advanced Algorithms and Data Structures. Responsible for the timely and accurate evaluation of individual works, covering the design and analysis of algorithms and data structures with adherence to established standards.
highlights: Amortized analysis, Fibonacci heaps, Randomized data structures and Expected running time analysis, Skip lists etc...

volunteer.summary: The woman in mathematics directed reading program (DRP) is an initiative that aims to provide an opportunity for undergraduate students (mentees), who identify as women or underrepresented gender identities, to work with graduate students on a mathematical project. During this time I mentored two undergraduates on machine learning methods (latent space models) and measures of statistical depth (and combinatorial data depth) for out-of-distribution diction methods.

Organizer for the Geometry Algorithms and Distributed Algorithms open problem solving sessions. These meetings were a platform for new students and other members of the lab to collaborate on open problems in the fields of Computational Geometry, Graph Algorithms, Distributed Algorithms, etc...

awards.title: President's Academic Excellence Award
awards.summary: Awarded to graduate students registered full time in a PhD program with high academic standing. ($840)

awards.title: Directed Reading Program Bursary
awards.summary: Awarded for serving as a graduate mentor. ($1000)

awards.title: Vector Institute Research Bursary
awards.summary: Awarded to full-time graduate studies at a Canadian educational institution during the Fall 2022 and/or Winter 2023 semesters in good academic standing and are supervised by a Vector Faculty Member. ($6000)

awards.title: University of Waterloo Graduate Scholarship
awards.summary: Awarded to graduate students registered full time in a Master's program with a minimum first-class (80%) cumulative average in their current program or over the last two full-time academic years. ($4,000)

awards.title: Faculty of Science Undergraduate Research Award
awards.awarder: University of Manitoba, Canada, Stephane Durocher.
awards.summary: Awarded to undergraduate students to fund their research while working under the supervision of individual professors. This was awarded to me twice working under Stephane Durocher. ($10,000)

awards.title: Philosophia Mathematica Prize in Applied Mathematics.
awards.summary: Awarded to best applied mathematics student in either second or third year. ($3850)
